function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Importation of dengue from dengue-affected areas through air travel","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Relationship between air travel volume and imported dengue cases","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Seasonal variation in the rate of imported dengue cases","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Presence of aedes mosquitoes in europe","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"International travel and transmission of denv","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Historical local transmission events","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Integration of environmental monitoring in public health surveillance systems","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"High risk values for wnv infection in specific regions","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Dengue dispersal through air traffic","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Reliance on external data sources for wnf case data and temperature anomalies may introduce inaccuracies and inconsistencies.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Overreliance on temperature anomalies and environmental variables may overlook other important risk factors for wnv transmission.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration of human and behavioral factors in wnv transmission risk assessment.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Elevated temperature accelerating viral replication and transmission of wnv","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Link between heat waves and wnf outbreaks in europe","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Correlation between temperature deviations and wnf cases","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Suitable environmental conditions for malaria transmission, including warmer temperatures, low elevation, and intensive agriculture","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biological and environmental drivers of west nile virus wnv transmission, including bird and vector population densities","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Continuing transmission of p. vivax by indigenous vectors in areas with permissive environmental and climatic conditions","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Exclusion of cases with travel history from the analysis","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Reliance on geo-referenced environmental and climatic information for spatial modeling","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Importation of vector-borne diseases","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Autochthonous transmission of malaria","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Continued importation of malaria cases","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Integration of climatic, weather, environmental, and health data","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dissemination of results to various stakeholders","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Continuous assembly of data from various sources","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Significant time lags in traditional surveillance methods for health endpoints","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Geographic shift in infectious diseases leading to expansion of disease burden into new areas","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of proactive approach to deal with drivers of infectious diseases","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Environmental and climatic conditions contributing to the upsurge of vector-borne diseases vbd such as wnf and malaria in southeast europe.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Social inequality as a factor in the emergence and transmission cycle of malaria in greece, particularly among migrant workers from endemic countries.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequacy of traditional public health strategies to cope with the public health challenges associated with global environmental change and emergence of vbd in the european union.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Lack of pathogen surveillance in the blood supply","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Delayed access to healthcare for vbd patients","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Emerging vbd threats due to environmental/climate change, travel, and socio-economic factors","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Urbanization, urban sprawl, and high population densities are associated with vector-borne disease vbd emergence.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Habitat encroachment and destruction lead to displacement of wild animals, affecting exposure patterns to infectious pathogens.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Social and demographic changes, including demographic shifts and social inequality, lead to disproportionate vulnerability to infectious diseases.","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of adequate surveillance systems to cope with the arrival and dispersal of tropical pathogens associated with warmer temperatures.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Contamination of blood products from donors infected with known or unknown pathogens represents a significant threat to the blood supply and public health.","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Globalization and environmental change contribute to the spread of vector-borne diseases vbd","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Approximately 60% of human pathogens are estimated to be of zoonotic origin","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Land-use can indirectly determine the spread of zoonotic diseases through exposure pathways in different urban, sub-urban, and rural settings","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Different effects of methods on different types of buildings could lead to inconsistent control of disease transmission","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Positive effect of methods in all types of buildings may lead to a false sense of security","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Varying effects of methods in different risk buildings may result in inadequate disease prevention in high-risk buildings","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate use of infectious prevention methods in building design and construction","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Insufficient consideration of building type in the effectiveness of prevention methods","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Concentration of participants from high-risk regions in the study","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Unequal variances between buildings due to method type","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"}]}
